title: Professional Minute-Taking and Documentation

sections.title: The Art of Effective Minute-Taking
sections.content:
Taking minutes is more than just recording what people say; it is about capturing the **decisions made** and the **actions assigned**. In a B2 professional context, your minutes should be concise, objective, and easy to scan.

### Key Components of Minutes
- **Header**: Name of the meeting, date, time, and location.
- **Attendance**: List of those present and those who sent apologies (absent with a valid reason).
- **Approval of Previous Minutes**: Confirming the last meeting's record was accurate.
- **Main Discussion Points**: A summary of the key arguments (not a word-for-word transcript).
- **Decisions**: Clear statements of what was agreed upon.
- **Action Items**: Specific tasks assigned to individuals with deadlines.
- **AOB (Any Other Business)**: Small items not on the original agenda.
- **Next Meeting**: Date and time of the next session.

### Tone and Style
Minutes should always be written in the **past tense** and use **objective language**. Avoid emotive adjectives (e.g., instead of 'a heated discussion', use 'a detailed discussion').

sections.title: Action Items and Following Up
sections.content:
The most important part of any meeting is what happens after it. An **Action Item** must follow the **SMART** criteria (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound).

**Common format:**
- *"**Action**: [Name] to [Task] by [Date]"*
- *"**Action**: HR to circulate the new privacy policy by Friday 12th."*

As an administrator, you are often responsible for 'chasing' these actions. This requires a balance of persistence and professional politeness.

sections.title: Grammar: Advanced Reported Speech for Summarising
sections.content:
When writing minutes or summaries, we rarely use 'said' or 'told'. Instead, we use **reporting verbs** that convey the intent of the speaker.

### Reporting Verbs
1. **Suggest / Recommend (+ -ing or + that)**:
   - *"The Chair **suggested moving** the deadline to October."*
   - *"The team **recommended that** we hire an external consultant."*

2. **Urge (+ object + to + infinitive)**:
   - *"The CEO **urged the team to focus** on efficiency."*

3. **Point out / State (+ that)**:
   - *"Finance **pointed out that** the budget was already exceeded."*

4. **Agree / Refuse (+ to + infinitive)**:
   - *"Marketing **agreed to provide** the assets by EOD."*

### Tense Shift Reminder
When reporting what was said in the past, the tenses usually shift back:
- *"I **am** working on it"* → *"He said he **was** working on it."*
- *"We **will** finish tomorrow"* → *"They said they **would** finish the following day."*

sections.title: PhraseBank: Meetings & Documentation
sections.content:
1. **to take the minutes** — To record what is said and decided in a meeting.
2. **to send apologies** — To notify that you cannot attend a meeting.
3. **to convene a meeting** — To call people together for a formal meeting.
4. **to chair a meeting** — To lead or manage the meeting.
5. **to move to the next item** — To change the topic to the next point on the agenda.
6. **to table a discussion** — To postpone a discussion until a later time.
7. **matters arising** — Issues that have come up from the previous meeting's minutes.
8. **unanimous decision** — A decision where everyone agrees.
9. **casting vote** — A deciding vote cast by the chair when there is a tie.
10. **to circulate the agenda** — To send the list of topics to participants before the meeting.
11. **to keep a record** — To maintain a written account of events.
12. **verbatim** — Using exactly the same words as were used originally (usually avoided in minutes).
13. **proposer / seconder** — People who formally suggest and support a motion.
14. **to adjourn a meeting** — To break off a meeting with the intention of resuming it later.
15. **action-oriented** — Focused on tasks and results rather than just talk.

sections.title: Weekly Deliverable (Portfolio)
sections.content:
### Task: Mock Meeting Minutes
Watch a short professional meeting (or use a provided transcript) and produce a set of formal minutes.

**Requirements:**
1. Use a standard **Header** and **Attendance** section.
2. Summarise at least three discussion points using **advanced reporting verbs** (urged, suggested, pointed out).
3. Include a clear **Action Items** table with at least three tasks, owners, and deadlines.

sections.title: Managing Virtual & Hybrid Meetings
sections.content:
In the modern workplace, administrative professionals must master the logistics of virtual (Zoom/Teams) and hybrid meetings. This requires additional technical and social coordination.

### Digital Logistics
- **Tech Check**: Ensuring all participants can see and hear before starting the agenda.
- **Inclusive Turn-taking**: Actively managing the 'hand raise' feature to ensure remote participants are not ignored.
- **Virtual Whiteboards**: Using tools like Miro or Mural to capture ideas in real-time.

### Digital Etiquette
- **Muting protocol**: Reminding participants to mute when not speaking to avoid background noise.
- **Camera usage**: Setting clear expectations on whether cameras should be 'on' or 'off'.

sections.title: Drafting Executive Summaries of Reports
sections.content:
While minutes record a meeting, an **Executive Summary** condenses a long report or proposal into a single page. It is designed for senior managers who may not have time to read the full document.

### The 'Golden Rules' of Summarising
1. **Focus on the 'So What?'**: What is the main finding or recommendation?
2. **Use Bullet Points**: Make the data easy to scan.
3. **Eliminate Jargon**: Use clear, professional language.
4. **Highlight the ROI**: For proposals, clearly state the benefit or cost-saving.

### Useful Reporting Verbs for Summaries
- *"The report **concludes that**..."*
- *"It is **recommended that**..."*
- *"Data **indicates a 15% increase** in..."*

sections.title: RolePlay: The High-Stakes Board Meeting
sections.content:
In high-stakes board meetings, accuracy is paramount. The administrator must navigate conflicting opinions and formal procedures like motions and seconders.

### Scenario Description
The Board is debating a 20% budget cut to the HR department. Tensions are high.

### Key Phrases for the Admin/Secretary:
- *"I'm sorry, could I just clarify the exact wording of that motion?"*
- *"For the record, who was the seconder for that proposal?"*
- *"Could we confirm the deadline for that specific action item before we move on?"*

### Professional Conduct
1. **Neutrality**: Never join the debate; your job is to record it.
2. **Clarity**: If a decision is vague, interrupt politely to ensure the minutes will be clear.
3. **Confidentiality**: Board minutes often contain sensitive data; ensure secure storage and restricted circulation.

objectives: Produce professional, concise, and objective meeting minutes
Identify and format SMART action items effectively
Apply advanced reporting verbs to summarise discussions accurately
Use professional terminology to manage meeting flow and documentation
Coordinate the logistics and etiquette of virtual and hybrid meetings
Draft concise executive summaries of long reports for senior management

keyTerms.definition: The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the proceedings of that meeting valid.
A list of items to be discussed at a formal meeting.
The official written record of what was discussed and decided at a meeting.
A formal notification that someone is unable to attend a meeting.
A meeting where some participants are together in a physical location and others join virtually.
A short document or section of a document that summarizes a longer report or proposal.
Any Other Business: a slot at the end of a meeting for items not on the agenda.
